Active hands, busy hands cleaning all manner of people in all manner of ways. Hands stropping, shaving the razor bl down a soap-buried cheek, trimming the hair with great sn of the scissors -- hands busy polishing boots with a boot brush, and the great hand of the city clock pointing to 7

The basements where the hotel boys get dressed, little  elbowroom and plenty of noise. Boys are busily slicking  their hair down -- scenting themselves with a dash of  eau-de-Cologne -- giving an extra shine to their shoes -- tilting their caps at an angle, just so -- and smoking  cigarette after cigarette. In a corner sits Clyde, uneasy and bashful. He is washed, his hair is cut, he is spick a span in his new uniform. He is terribly anxious, as a  schoolboy before an examination -- as a soldier going int battle. Ratterer enters towards him, looks him over  authoritatively with the air of a superior being -- fixes Clyde's tie, pulls at his uniform -- fixes his cap at the right slant over his eyebrow and then starts to give him  instructions. Having adjusted Clyde's clothes,  unconsciously noticing him as clean and neat, Ratterer  becomes friendly. He sits there at his ease, his knees  crossed, flicking the ash off his cigarette with a finger the hand that holds it. Clyde sits on the very edge of th bench, his knees apart, striving to control his anxiety.  Ratterer begins:
"In the morning the blinds have to be pulled up -- at nig they have to be let down -- at sundown switch on the smal light and always put fresh water in the closet."
As Ratterer speaks we see on the screen the mechanical  routine of an hotel boy's duties.  A day-boy pulling up the blinds.  A night-boy letting down the blinds.

Ratterer continues: that when the room is ready one can s by the door a few moments before leaving, and if this  procedure results in a tip it must be gratefully  acknowledged -- and if it doesn't one must show no trace of disappointmen and bow oneself out. And as he continues we continue to see the illustrations the routine.
And Ratterer continues: that no matter what happens, the  guest is always right, and he adds that, in a good day, i all goes well, Clyde may possibly make as much as six or  seven dollars in tips.
Six or seven dollars! Clyde is speechless with joy.

The signal bell, and Clyde stands in single file with the other boys ready for duty .... A second bell and the boys through a small door, through which as it opens is heard  penetrating a buzz of voices and the distant music of the hotel orchestra. The army of boys approaches large gilt  doors and, as these are flung back, Clyde is plunged into the maelstrom and dazzle of a gorgeous gilt and mirror ha decorated for a ball.

Immediately by the doors whence he has emerged is a  cloakroom. Piles of rich furs heap upon the counter. A wo beside him flings back her mantle and emerges from it, wh and naked by contrast. The silks, the exquisite dresses, precious stones and elegance bewilder and increase the  anxiety of Clyde.
On the highly polished floor of the vestibule of this hal stands the file of boys ready for orders.
To Clyde, these are not boys on duty but almost the Guard at the changing of the guard at Buckingham Palace. He fee that this is a parade, at which he will be promoted gener at least.
The parade is finished, groups of the boys disperse in th several directions, Clyde is in a group that sits down on long bench waiting for calls.
Barely have they sat down when a bell rings -- from out o small window an order is given, and the first boy in the  line runs off to fulfil it.

Bell after bell, order after order, boy after boy -- the  long line of boys keeps moving up as those at the head mo up, returning to sit at the tail when their tasks are  completed. As, little by little, Clyde sees himself   approaching the head of the bench his anxiety grows stron and stronger. His movements are more nervous and there is bewildered expression in his eyes.

And on the background of the accompaniment -- of bells of orders being cried out -- of the music from the restauran and the laughter of the guests -- occasional fragments of Ratterer's continued instructions continue to penetrate t us: "You gotta use the employees' elevator" -- "Even numb are on the left of the corridor, odd numbers on the right

And Clyde approaches nearer and ever nearer to the end of the bench -- and the bells ring ever more frequently and tempo of everyone's movements hastens and speeds. It is h turn now. He trembles in his anxiety like a race horse at the "Off". A bell. An order rings out: "Number 500" -- Cl dashes up the short flight of steps to the gates of the  elevators on the Bel-пїЅtage.
The employees' elevator is full.
At the last moment he squeezes into a neighbouring elevat The doors shut to, deadening the sound of the orchestra, laughter and noises of the great hall.

The elevator is packed with men in evening dress. Clyde i wedged into the midst of satin lapels and stiff white cuf The elevator goes up and up, leaving behind it the sound the ever receding music. The glitter of the evening dress suits and the polish of the men only increase the anxiety Clyde. The elevator stops. Clyde squeezes aside to let  someone in and then darts out himself.

The doors of the elevator swing to behind him, and Clyde left, solitary, in the carpeted silence of a long empty  corridor. At first he runs quickly, but then more slowly it seems sacrilege to run on the soft sinking pile of thi carpet.
He stops before the big double doors of No. 500, brushes hands over his hair, gives a twist to his tie, to his cuf and knocks. "Come in," is heard from behind the door.

Clyde opens the door. It is dark in the room; only one li shines from behind a screen. A man's hand with money in i reaches out from behind the screen and a masculine voice heard telling him to go buy a pair of garters. "Pink ones," adds suddenly a woman's voice from behind th screen. "Yes, sir," stammers Clyde in his confusion and runs down the corridor towards the elevator.

A Negro boy is in it, guiding the elevator, and together  they start going down. "New?" enquires the Negro. "You'll soon get used to it," and, learning his errand gives him  directions for finding the hotel shops.
The doors of the elevator slide open, Clyde rushes out. T doors close behind him.

Clyde is in the shop. The woman behind the counter is  finishing wrapping the garters and hands Clyde, together  with the package, a bill and a ten-cent tip. Noticing his pleased surprise she tells him that every time he buys  anything there he will receive 10 per cent commission.

Clyde rushes out of the shop. He is lost in the series of great halls. Through Morocco -- through Venice -- through rooms in Empire and in Gothic style, through samples of a the world he hurries frantically. At last he is back in t main entrance hall, filled with guests in their gorgeous  dresses.  He threads his way through the great crowds, an once again at the last moment manages to squeeze into the elevator.
The elevator is crowded with ladies. Amidst the expensive dresses and perfumes and the nudity of the bared backs  stands the trembling Clyde, his excitement having passed bounds.

A bell. Clyde dives through the bevy of ladies and stops  before No. 500. The door opens, and in front of the  decorated screen stands a man in radiantly glittering  dressing gown. Clyde bends and obsequiously hands him the package, the bill and the change. The man absent-mindedly takes the package, puts the change into his pocket, and  screws up and throws away the bill--then he looks at the  garters and then at Clyde. Exactly as instructed, Clyde  stands in the same place, shifting from foot to foot. The man throws open his dressing gown with a gesture, takes a fifty-cent piece out of his vest pocket and gives it to  Clyde. Clyde cannot believe it. He is numb with  astonishment. To look at the garters the man turns on the light, and with the click of the switch the room suffuses with brilliance, as the glow of happiness suffuses Clyde' face.  "Fifty cents."  An unknown voice is heard screaming it and a smile almost of exaltation brightens the whole face of Clyde.  "Fifty cents."  Still louder screams the strange voice, and together with the cry the orchestra is heard playing a wild, happy marc As though at High Mass the music peals forth, and the hot resembles a mighty cathedral. Like an organ swells forth huge proud volume of music and a tremendous chorus of hum voices rends the air asunder behind the whole small being the youthful Clyde, clasping in his fists his fifty-cent  piece.
And as the screen fades and grows darker, so the mighty  notes of the music grow fainter and their sound slowly  fades --
And there rises the image of the poor mission hall and th sound of its congregations singing psalms.
Clyde runs through the mission hall into his room, closin the door behind him.

He goes to pick up his money box but it is there no longe Only the fragments of it are upon the sill. Then he  unclenches his fist and in the palm of his hand are to be seen silver coins to the amount of several dollars. And with the same gesture as that with which the man had  thrown back his dressing gown and given Clyde his first t Clyde now throws back his coat and thrusts the money into his vest pocket. Then, slapping his pocket with his hand looks at himself in the mirror and smiles his first smile And together with this first smile are heard from behind door the strains of a joyous song such as "Everybody's  happy."

It is a morning, and boys are filing through the office o Mr. Squires. Mr. Squires sits at his desk and each as he  passes lays a dollar on the table, to be greeted sometime by a nod. Mr. Squires appears casual, but we can see from his glance that he is watching carefully to make sure of tribute. The little dollar pile grows and Clyde adds his  quota.  "Quite at home now, eh!"  -- greets Squires as he pockets the money.  "Yes, sir," replies Clyde and goes.

Clyde goes into the dressing room, smokes a cigarette, an in a carefree knowing way, dons his hotel uniform. With a practised hand he smooths his hair, flips the ashes off h cigarette, ties his tie and laughs at the cracks of his  colleagues, among whom is Ratterer.
A bell is heard, and the boys get into line.

As on the first day, they all go into the hall, but the h now no longer seems as grand to Clyde. A morning,  businesslike atmosphere pervades it -- emptiness -- sever The tempo of the successive bell-ringings is no longer  frenzied, but slower, deliberate. And as bell follows bel there passes before us, in glimpse after glimpse, the  fragments of life as they pass before a bellhop, the mora face that society presents to him. The boys seated on the bench are quietly yawning and bored.
A bell.
Clyde jumps up and runs to the office.
A happy and bright couple of newlyweds ask for a room. Th clerk tells them the number, and gives Clyde the keys. Cl takes their luggage and leads them to the elevator.

In the room, obedient to Ratterer's instructions, Clyde g through all the necessary operations. He opens the blinds the windows, checks the electric bulbs, sees if there is in the inkpot, water in the pitcher, and goes into the  bathroom.  Left alone, the couple kiss. Obeying Ratterer's instructions, Clyde changes the water the carafe.
At the sound of the running water, the newlyweds start an look guiltily at Clyde, standing in the doorway.  He smiles back in answer to their smile.
A bell.
A second boy on duty jumps up.

He carefully knocks on the door of another room. "Come in a voice is heard to call out. The boy enters. He is carry a large bundle of newspapers Once in the room he sees through the half-open door into bathroom. In the bath, her back to him, sits a woman comb out her wet hair.  "It's our wedding day today," says the woman.  Her husband grunts unintelligibly in answer, and starts  picking out the papers he wants from the boy.  The woman, seeing a youth, gives a scream. The man laughs her fright and hides himself behind the paper with the  callous expression a one who thinks such modesty from her unnecessary at her age.
7  A third bell.
A third boy on duty jumps up.

With a tray on which are bottles of soda water he enters room. Within it, all is in dreadful disorder. A gramophon -- empty bottles -- cards -- and from behind the back of armchair can be seen the feet of a sleeping man. A woman lying in bed and abusing a second man who is pouring a dr for himself out of a hip-flask. The woman, having said wh she wanted to, turns her back on him.

"Behave yourself," the man says, as he sees the boy enter The woman in irritation, to spite him, throws her blanket off her, sits up and chucks the boy under the chin.  Sensing a quarrel, the man gestures for the boy to get ou
A fourth bell.

A fourth boy on duty, handsome, sunburnt, closes the door behind him. In the foreground of the room he has entered baskets of flowers. He hears a woman's voice, as if calli out his name. He straightens up, and smiles a knowing smi Sitting in an armchair, the woman motions with her hand. it are numerous bracelets, rings, and her fingers hold a  long cigarette holder.   The fourth boy on duty approaches her.
Three bells ring one after the other.  Three boys jump up and run off.

In a room stands a woman, who is sobbing in terrible  distress. Mr. Squires is annoyed, he is scolding her as s packs her things into a trunk. The woman says: "What a fo I've been -- and he walking straight out like that and  leaving me," and at that moment the three boys enter. The woman finishes writing out a telegram, and a boy take it, then waits for the money. The sobbing woman searches her purse and cannot find any money. Mr. Squires takes th money out of his own pocket and the boy runs out into the corridor.
The fourth boy circumspectly leaves the room of the woman with the cigarette holder, and, folding a bundle of dolla hides them in his pocket.

"We can wait two or three days, but you will have to chan your room," Squires motions to the other two boys to take away the sobbing woman's luggage.  In another part of the room two stout Negro women are  pulling the bedding and table cloths off the beds and  tables.
Clyde and Ratterer are going down the stairs carrying tru
"You haven't forgotten," says Ratterer, "that we're going out tonight?"  "Oh, no," answers Clyde.
From the room vacated by the deserted woman we can hear t laughter of the Negro maids, changing the linen. One of the plump women pinches a bellhop who has just com into the room.

In the room where they undress, the boys, finished with  their duties, are changing their clothes, and laughing at one of their number who is imitating the sobbing woman. Ratterer is biting his lips in anticipation of the  night-out; showing an imitation of the "Danse du Ventre" Clyde, comically exaggerating the snake-like movement, as sample of what he is to see that evening. "And gee, next  week, Clyde, that will be a time. I know a fellow who's a gardener and the people there will be away. We can take  their car easy, one of the fellows here can drive. And  we'll get some girls and we will have a time! Don't forge Having divested themselves of uniform vests and caps, the boys are dressing in smart evening dress, hats, fastening up the fancy bows of their ties, fixing their silk pocket handkerchiefs, and fastening the laces of their shoes in  extravagant bows. They powder, scent themselves with  eau-de-Cologne, oil their hair, put cigars into the pocke of their vests and, in such a costume, Clyde looks like a illustration for a fashion magazine.
At the back of the huge hotel, with merry jokes and an  important stride, a group of the boys goes but dressed up like men. The group disappears in the darkness.
The window of Clyde's room. Dawn behind the window. And i the room a lamp is burning and in a sitting position on t bed, his mother has fallen asleep waiting for him.
Clyde, coming in from the street, cautiously opens the do to the mission building, over which hangs a sign: How Lon Since You Wrote to your Mother?

On tiptoe Clyde walks through the big empty hall, past th empty harmonium. He quietly enters his room, goes to the  mirror and studies his dishevelled look consequent in the riotously spent evening. Suddenly he notices the lighted  lamp, turns to the bed and sees his mother. Her open eyes seem to have been watching him. But they had been unseein she had other thoughts. Startled, he is confused by  awareness of his appearance, and quickly starts to take o the bright links from his cuffs. "Clyde," he hears his mother's voice.

The mother is sitting on the bed, she looks long at him w strange eyes. Clyde is worried. He hides the bright cuff  links, but the mother remarks nothing about him, she says "Clyde, couldn't you help me find some money?"  And her rough, big, coarse hand passes over her face.  "You see -- Esta -- has been left by the man who ... by h husband.... She is in a terrible plight -- I will sell yo father's ring, then you know -- we have -- a silver jug a plate -- but it won't be enough."  Clyde's surprise and worry pass. He begins to feel the  superiority of his position. He puts his cuff links back, and with an intonation which is still humble but has a  different ring in it, promises to find money for his moth His mother asks him to add five dollars a week for the re of his room, so that with this money she can pay back the money she has borrowed. Clyde agrees half-heartedly and  makes a sour face. "You see, mother, I don't earn very much and then I wante money rather specially next week," he says.

A luxurious open Packard drives out of a garage. Ratterer dressed in smart evening dress, closes the garage doors. the wheel sits a boy of about sixteen or seventeen years, dressed as elegantly as Ratterer. Looking about them, the turn into an alley where two of their companions (one of  them Clyde) and four young girls, powdered and dressed up are waiting for them. They take their places in the car,  and Ratterer says to the boy at the wheel:
"Well, there -- no one saw us -- I told you it would be s as houses."  And, with a grinding of gears, the Packard starts off.

A young girl is sitting on Clyde's knees. She presses clo to him, and he derives from her contact a trembling sense pleasure. But Clyde is inexperienced, he is shy. The car  goes rushing by pretty roads, the girls squeal at every t pressing closer to the boys. Time passes. They have gone The sun is setting, and the boys look at their watches.  "We must be getting back now," says Ratterer, "or we shal be late for work."  And with a risky movement the Packard is headed round.  Looking at his colleagues, Clyde slowly grows more certai of himself and, seeing how they press the girls closer to them and boldly kiss them, Clyde embraces his companion w helping him, kisses him herself. The car stops at a railw crossing, letting a long freight train pass by. Ratterer nervous and tells the driver: "Step on it -- there'll be a fearful bawling-out."  When the last freight wagon opens up the road for them, t car at a mad speed dashes through the evening darkness,  along the wet roads.

The first snow is falling. The wet flakes cover the  windshield and close the eyes of those in the car. At a  street crossing they cannot pass because of the steady  traffic across. It is five minutes to six on the watch. T boys no longer embrace the girls, they are anxious, nervo beat their knees with their hands, twist their watches in their hands, stamp their feet on the boards, and wait for the moment to get across the crossing. At the very first  opportunity, at high speed, the car flashes past and dash into an alley. At the turning, from out of a corner, a  little girl comes out, and the car knocks her down.  Terrified, the driver, his face livid with fright,  accelerates his speed, and the car, humming like an  aeroplane, dashes past. "Stop that car" -- "He's killed a child" -- "Stop, stop!" "Stop them!" Cries and whistles are heard from the alleys and, humming ever louder, the Packard goes ever quicker  with its terrified occupants.  "Switch off the lights!"  cries Ratterer, and the driver turns the switch to off.  Without lights, through the dark alleys, the car dashes o The sirens of police motorcycles are heard behind them.  Hearing these sirens, the driver pushes the speed up to t very highest the car can go.
The sirens are heard ever nearer and a group of  motorcyclists come dashing into the camera.
Skidding at a turning, the Packard is thrown against the  pavement, jerks sideways, cuts into a mound of stones and wooden boards, and, crackling with a loud noise, it turns its side.

Clyde jumps to his feet, having been thrown out through a open door, and, trembling with fear and foreboding, looks around him. The roar of the police sirens approaches near becomes more and more terrifying. Wiping the blood off hi face, Clyde runs into a narrow alley between tall buildin climbs over a fence, over a mound of bricks, runs through lot of dust and rubbish and reaches the outskirts of the  town, where the prairie begins. Looking back, he sees,  through the curtain of falling snow, the lights of the ci hears the roar of the police sirens, the whistles, the cr He sees behind him the ruin of his job, the scandal that  cuts him from his home. Clyde trembles and, turning, goes away into the fields, hiding in the thickly, fast falling snow.
The darkness lightens to disclose the anxious family of  Clyde intent upon a letter.

The letter is the first news they have received from him a year. In it he has related something of his difficultie and fears following the Packard accident, his scraping of existence from town to town. Now he is working in Chicago small job and he is sorry he cannot yet send money. The family is deeply moved. The father stares in front of him. Clyde's mother pauses, and puts down the letter. She cannot finish it. The little girl ends the reading of the letter.  At the end of the letter is set Chicago, the date and the year.

The letter fades out and we see the city of Chicago and,  resplendent on one of the buildings, is an electric sign. The sign outlines a collar, a collar gorgeous, in  apotheosis -- straight lines of light, like a fiery star, like a halo, shoot out around it, bursting and extinguish like the opening and shutting of a fist. And ever and ano beneath it, shows the illuminated signature: Samuel  Griffiths.

The camera pans down, and we see a man with a travelling beside him on the pavement and an umbrella. His head stri the background of the lighted collar and over his shoulde bursts out the illuminated sign: Samuel Griffiths. He is  standing outside a sort of residential club, a hostelry m more sober of exterior than the hotel of previous reels.  A porter runs up to him, takes his grip away from him, an follows him through the doors of the club.
Having checked-in for a room, he hands a visiting card to the clerk. The name on it is: Samuel Griffiths.

Once in his room he rings down, asking that newspapers be brought him, and, while waiting for them, he looks out of the window, pondering upon the advertisement of his wares A boy comes in with the papers. He offers him a tip, but boy, shifting as if embarrassedly on his feet, refuses to accept the money, saying: "Excuse me, sir, but are you Mr. Samuel Griffiths?"  "Yes," answers the surprised guest.

"Well, excuse me, sir, my name is Clyde Griffiths. My fat is your brother."  "Oh, indeed!" exclaims Samuel Griffiths, glancing at him  shrewdly. Clyde bears this inspection. He has been throug good deal. He is thinner and more subdued, but still  sensitive-looking and handsome.

In the corridor an employee of the club, in the same unif as Clyde, is vacuuming the carpets. On the stairs, a seco servant in uniform is polishing the brass balusters. A th servant is washing a large windowpane, through which can seen the city, and the advertisement of the collars.

7  Clyde is standing deferentially before Samuel Griffiths,  who, patronising and seated, is bringing a homily to an e "If you want to get out of the rut and be somebody, and c to come down to our part of the world, I think I should b ready to give you a chance to show what you have in you a what you are capable of."  Clyde, but still deferential, thanks him with warmth and  then, hearing a bell in the corridor, hurries out of the  room.
The interior of the Griffiths' household. The family -- h wife, son Gilbert, and daughter Bella, are breakfasting.
"Well, what is he doing now," Gilbert, displeased, desire to know.
"He serves in a club in the capacity of a messenger boy," Mr. Griffiths answers.

"But father says he is very, very much like you, and much handsomer than any of our other cousins."  "Bella!" -- her mother stops her. "I still can't understand," says Gilbert, who really has strong resemblance to Clyde, only looking a little more  sullen and less docile, "why father takes on people when have difficulty in keeping those who already work for us. Besides I can imagine what will be said when people know  this messenger boy is a relative of ours."  "It is too late now to do anything," says the mother. "He arriving, and you had better try to control your rudeness

Neatly, if inconspicuously dressed, with a small grip in hand, Clyde approaches the gates of the Griffiths factory The watchman takes him for Gilbert, opens the gates for h and greets him:  "Good day, Mr. Gilbert."  "Excuse me, my name is Clyde. But I should like to see Mr Gilbert," Clyde answers with an embarrassed smile. He passes through the gates.
"Well, what do you want?" the secretary asks, without  lifting her head.

"My name is Clyde Griffiths. I have a letter with me from Uncle."  And the secretary, lifting her head, does not know how to act, so surprised is she at the extraordinary likeness of Clyde and Gilbert, whom she quickly rings on the telephon
Having heard the answer, she says: "You may enter," and l him to a door, with the sign: Mr. Gilbert Griffiths.
And having entered, Clyde sees himself as he likes to ima himself. It is Gilbert -- his cousin. Both lose poise at resemblance.

Telephone bells ring -- machines are working -- the colla run along endless bands -- men and women are busy with  different kinds of work -- smoke comes out of the factory chimneys -- the typewriters click in the Griffiths factor

The discomfort of Gilbert shows itself in an icy coldness the discomfort of Clyde shows itself in a nervousness and hesitation in speech. The gulf between them has grown wid with the advance of the conversation.  In Gilbert's office, the conversation continues.  Gilbert: "Father tells me you've had no practical experie You don't know accounting?"  Clyde: "I am sorry to say I do not."  Gilbert: "You don't take down shorthand, or something lik that?"  Clyde: "No, sir, I do not."

Gilbert: "In that case it will perhaps be best for you to start working in the shrinking room; that is the departme in which the first stage of the business takes place. By  this means you will be able to learn our trade from the v beginning."
Gilbert presses a button, and in answer to it a well-dres young woman with a scowl on her face enters.
Gilbert: "And so, good-bye, Clyde. Mrs. Bradley will tell you all you want to know, and tomorrow you must be at wor by 7 a.m."
And without shaking hands, Gilbert bows officially to Cly
Clyde comes out of the factory gates and walks in leisure fashion along the streets.

And all at once he finds himself before an imposing mansi with bronze deer in the garden and marble lions over the  entrance gate. It attracts his admiration.  "Can you tell me please -- whose house is this?" he asks a passer-by.

"You don't know? Why that's the home of Samuel Griffiths, one of our leading citizens."  "Thank you," answers Clyde and, though rendered puny by t contrast, yields himself to the luxury of reflecting on h connection, however humble, with this gorgeous family. Th mansion slowly fades in the darkness.

And in the darkness the factory looms roar, and the steam machinery hisses, and out of the clouds of steam appears  working a perspiring, wet, miserable-looking Clyde. He seems unable to get the hang of his work. The material boiling in the kettle keeps falling off his tongs, and  spraying his chest with boiling water; he is despairing,  lost, and helplessly looks around him.  The foreman comes to his help. He emphasizes the name "Mr Griffiths," sits by him and starts to explain and show hi how to handle his work. Around Clyde are working experien men, their movements are calm and sure. And, after seeing them, we realise how little suited Clyde is to this work, how unhandy he is in character, how difficult he finds it be in this low-built, stuffy room, among red-hot kettles, clouds of steam and the roar of the machines. And when the factory whistle blows, Clyde sighs deeply wi relief.

Weary and exhausted he comes into his room and sits down the bed. The furnishings of his room express everything t is dingy and horrible in a boardinghouse existence. No mo comfortable, in reality, than those of his room in the  mission, they differ only in being more oppressive. A knock at the door, his landlady enters, asks him if the is anything he wants. She accents his name "Griffiths" in snobbery. "There's a letter for you, Mr. Griffiths," she adds, and  hands it to him.  The letter is an invitation.
Dear nephew,

Ever since your arrival, my husband has been away or busy Now, he is less occupied and we should be very glad to se you if you could come to dine tomorrow, Sunday. We will b quite alone, no guests. And there will be no need to dres
Your aunt,  Elizabeth Griffiths.

Once more Clyde stands before the gate with the marble li and the gardens with the bronze deer. But now he feels as though possessed of the magic key. He brushes his hair ba flicks a speck of dust off his carefully pressed dark sui fixes his tie and rings. A maid opens the door and leads to the drawing room. The room -- filled with different kinds of furniture,  bronzes, candelabras, little statuettes, flowers, covered carpets, with beautiful draperies -- amazes Clyde. He looks about him, and hears the swish of a silk skirt.  The swish approaches. Coming down the wide staircase can seen a pair of feet, and the swishing of the silk dress  increases. Mrs. Griffiths is coming down the stairs, a th faded, sweet-tempered woman.
"So you are my nephew," she says, coming up to Clyde.  "Yes," answers Clyde.

"I am very happy to meet you -- welcome," Mrs. Griffiths  greets him in formal manner.  "How do you like our city? We are very proud of our stree -- begins Mrs. Griffiths to the embarrassed youth. She is interrupted by the arrival of Griffiths himself, who take Clyde in with a penetrating look, and says:  "Well, it's good you came. It means you got fixed up.  Everything was done for you without me?"  "Yes, sir," answers Clyde.

"Well, that's perfect. I'm glad. Sit down, sit down."  The rattle of feet fast descending the staircase, and  Gilbert, in evening dress with a coat on, plunges into th hall. He speaks to his parents, ignoring Clyde except for nod. "Well, I'm going out now, mother," he says in an even voi

"Are you sure you have to go? You know Sondra Finchley is coming back with Bella and she wants to see you."  "No, I have to go."  He gives a quick side look at Clyde as if to tell his mot You know why I'm dining out tonight, pecks her forehead a hastily goes out. The signal neither escapes Clyde nor  increases his self-confidence.  Dinner is announced, and Clyde walks with his aunt and un through several large rooms, all satin and mahogany, each stiffer than the last.

Dinner is not a success. With a wave of laughter  the car stops under a street lamp at a corner, and, excit dishevelled, Clyde jumps out. Another burst of laughter a the car disappears.
Clyde turns the corner and sees a light in Roberta's room
Sighing wearily, Roberta drops onto the bed.
Clyde, standing on the porch, starts to push the outer do it opens.

Quietly Clyde enters Roberta's room. She turns a tear- stained face to him. "Clyde, where have you been? We have been alone together for weeks. What has happened?" Clyde  feels uncomfortable, so makes a show of irritation. "I to you, I've had to go to see my uncle. You know what it mea to me. You know I can't possibly refuse." Suddenly,  unexpectedly, she jumps up, grabs a bundle of newspapers turns towards him. "You're lying to me, Clyde." With  difficulty keeping back her sobs, she shows Clyde the  chronicle of his social life. One, two, three balls, more -- and in each among those present appears his name.
Scared lest they wake the family of the proprietors, they quarrel in whispers. Whispers of passion, but now not of  passionate love.

"You were with Miss Finchley," says the girl, and this  drives Clyde to lose his head. He runs up to Roberta, tak hold of her shoulders and brings her face nearer to his,  looking straight into her eyes.  And, seeing his face, his dear face, so close to her own, Roberta involuntarily forgets his neglect, and the old jo and tenderness for him appear in her expression.  And as the familiar charm reawakens, Clyde, instead of  striking her or scolding her as he had intended, kisses  Roberta. And when she throws back her head it seems to hi as though he is being held in the arms of Sondra. His  fingers clenched in her hair, with new strength and new  passion he kisses Roberta.
From the street we see the light go out behind Roberta's  window. Nearby, from some source unknown, the laughter of little child is heard in childish glee.
Once more the noise of the looms in the factory, the hiss of the steam machines, and the sound of the stamps markin the collars.

It is dark outside and the electric light is searing. It  outlines sharply unusual shadows on the faces of those  working. Roberta at her worktable is pale, sad and anxious. She  watches Clyde, striving to catch his eye. But Clyde will look at her.

Roberta takes a torn slip of paper and writes upon it a  note:  Clyde, I absolutely, absolutely must see you today.  Please come to see me after work or meet me somewhere. It is essential. Roberta.  Taking a basket of collars she passes by his desk and,  unseen by the others, throws him her note.

As Clyde finishes reading the note he sees Roberta's face nervous and full of anxiety. With a slight nod of the hea he agrees to meet her. He glances at a memorandum pad on table, inscribed: 10th January, Dinner at the Griffiths, once again nods to Roberta.
Slowly the noise of the machines dies and the jigging mel of an old-fashioned dance fills the air.

Clyde and Sondra are dancing one of those old-fashioned,  rapid jig-time dances in which everyone has to take part  together, and which consist of circles and pairs. A  Christmas tree and Christmassy decorations are in evidenc To the sound of handclaps beating with the music, Clyde - now in tails -- and Sondra advance, jigging, towards the  centre of the room, and circle hands on hips and back to  back in one of the figures of the dance.

By the walls a group of old ladies, made-up, powdered,  overdressed, scrutinise Clyde and criticise his manners a success in society. They say that the Griffiths have star receiving him only because it became impossible for them to do so when he was received by everyone else. Their smi at the Griffiths' discomfiture are vinegar. To the merry, frantic children's tune, Clyde and Sondra  whirl round in the frenzied closing figures of the dance.
The music stops with a burst of laughter. Clyde and Sondr run out into the hall and throw on their wraps and coats.
Outside the snow is pouring down and is slushy underfoot. Cars move away from the entrance.

Sondra and Clyde are in a car together. Sondra is driving The car pulls up outside her house. She looks at him thro half-closed lids and proposes: "Why don't you come in, Cl I'll fix you up a cup of hot chocolate before you go home Do you like chocolate?" "Oh, yes," says Clyde.

The kitchen amazes Clyde by its luxury, its cleanliness, glitter of its copper dishes and the large Norman-style  fireplace with bright logs burning in it. And Clyde says, spontaneously and sincerely: "What a marvellous kitchen!" "Do you think so? Aren't all kitchens the same?" Sondra a as she busies herself with the chocolate. She also looks  around the walls of the kitchen and brings her gaze to a  stop before the closed dresser. Having thought for a mome she goes to the dresser and opens wide its little doors.

An arsenal of crystal and silver services. Tumblers and  goblets that amaze Clyde by their number and glitter. And Sondra picks out the handsomest tumbler for chocolate,  pouring the chocolate out of a jug into the tumbler, she  sits down beside Clyde, near the fireplace, and says: "Is it cosy here?"  "It's very lovely with you here, Sondra," says Clyde.  "I'm pleased you're  satisfied," Sondra answers smiling  tenderly, and each notices the good looks of the other an both keep silent, not knowing what to say or what to do. "You've been very anxious to tell me something," Sondra a in a very low voice.

"I'd like to tell you a lot, but you forbid me to."  "I know what you'd like to tell me." Both get off the ben and he takes her hand in both of his. Clyde looks at her a faithful believer would look at a holy relic and under  this gaze she lowers her eyes and Clyde, who has never do so before, puts his arm about her and kisses her.

At the moment of this kiss the silver seems to glitter  dazzlingly on the open dresser -- the burning logs crash  throwing up sparks like fireworks, and for a few seconds  Sondra allows herself to be embraced. Then she gently pus him away without any anger and smilingly says: "Now you must leave, do you hear?" "Are you angry?" asks  Clyde.
Smiling, she shakes her head: "It is very late."  And Clyde makes a gesture with the hand, as does a  sportsman answering the ovations of a many-thousand crowd
The handsome crystal tumbler stands on the table filled w the untouched chocolate.

With a firm tread, humming the melody of that "hymn of  happiness", that same melody which passes as a theme moti through all his happy days, Clyde walks down the street,  already deep in snow, smiling to passers-by. The snow is  whirling down and pouring, a frenzied whirling blizzard.
He carefully enters the porch of Roberta's home and knock at the door. The door is immediately opened and Roberta,  still dressed in her day-dress, lets him into her room.

Her face is so very sad and frightened that it makes Clyd scrutinise her closely. "Do you remember, Clyde, you said that if ever a misfortune happened to me ... you would he me?"  "A misfortune?" asks Clyde, and he sees how Roberta sits  down on the bed lifting her hands to the waist of her dre
And again from some unknown source is heard the mocking  joyous laughter of a child.

A druggist's sign. The show window of a drug store. In it among the array of medicine and bottles, the cardboard  cutouts of nurses' figures and happy feeding children; th is an advertisement for milk, that for purgatives or cand Hanging over the glass of the drug store doors, a bright  illustrated sign of a naked little boy and his sympatheti father.  Looking through the window is a nurse and her  little charges, the children laughing, their attention  caught by a gaily-coloured advertisement.
And at the entrance to the drug store stands Clyde,  uncertain and embarrassed. He looks through the glass,  trying to inspect the clerk behind the counter, and he  sees --
-- a woman stands behind the counter, a saleslady.

Clyde grits his teeth, looks around him, and crosses the  road, stopping at another drug store. Looking inside, he  sees a man. Trembling with anxiety, he enters, and at the same time through the radio loudspeaker is heard a song s by children in a treble. Through the window we are able t see Clyde approach the counter, take off his hat, and,  embarrassed, ask something of the druggist.

And as Clyde's embarrassment increases, so does the volum of the children's voices increase in the song over the ra The druggist having listened to Clyde, shakes his head, a Clyde comes out onto the street. And at that moment, as  Clyde opens the door of the drug store, the radio childre finish singing, and are heard laughing over something in  sheer exuberance.
With quick steps, Clyde crosses past some little knots of children playing on the street. He stops at yet another d store, and looks in through the window.

A grey-haired, bewhiskered man is sitting there reading t newspaper. Next to the drug store is a phonograph shop. I its show window are cutouts of children and dogs listenin to a record. And, within the shop, a record is being play of a child's recitation, touching and yet at the same tim slightly comical.

Turning away from the window, Clyde enters the drug store and -- While the child's voice from the radio shop continues  declaiming how it loves its father and its mother, the  sunshine and the forest, Clyde once again takes off his h bends over the counter, and he repeats his question to th elderly man. And we see the greyhaired man grow angry, wa his hands about and raise his voice at Clyde; what he say we cannot hear through the glass of the window, but we do see Clyde grow confused, excuse himself and come out onto the street again.

With quick steps Clyde makes his way through the noisy, b streets. The lights are now lit. Gleams of light appear f the buildings, as lamps are turned on, illuminating the  various signs, advertisements and illustrations in the sh In the background is an enormous advertisement for milk, huge, laughing head of a child. Clyde stops before it,  thinking where to go. He looks around him -- on the roof tall building a children's jelly is being advertised.

As though feeling pursued by all these advertisements and signs, Clyde retreats into a dark alley. He still walks  slowly, not knowing where he should turn. He has to stop the corner of the street to let a heavy truck pass by, an as the truck passes, he notices that he is facing an obsc little drug store. Something, perhaps a man-of-the-world in the bearing of the druggist, inspires him with confide An expression of resolution comes into his face, and he  enters....
An ambulance with its red cross and long whining siren  dashes through the little street. The whine of the siren  dies away.

Clyde comes out of the drug store; as soon as he has pass from the view of the druggist he thrusts a small packet t he is holding deep into his coat pocket. He looks happier and his walk is firmer. He goes back through the streets has passed, his hand firmly gripping the package inside h pocket.  It is late. The lights fade, and in the growing darkness laughing posters of the children are no longer visible.

Clyde goes into Roberta's room. She is so frightened and  worried over what has befallen her that she no longer pay any attention to her looks. She is untidy, dressed in a  provincial-looking dressing gown and her movements are  bewildered and absent-minded. Clyde opens up the package, and takes out a bottle from it. Roberta snatches it from hands, lifts it to the light, and reads the instructions it. "We must hope that it will all plan itself out," Clyd says. They arrange that the following day, on his way to factory, he will pass Roberta's house, and if everything  works out well, she will raise the blinds, if not, the  blinds will only be drawn halfway. He kisses her, but his tender words are only mumbled.  "Oh, Clyde, Clyde!" Roberta cries, as she is left alone.

A Clyde who now appears much relieved enters his own room to find waiting for him on his table several small packag from a smart shop. He reads an accompanying note from  Sondra, her good wishes and greetings. These parcels she sent him in token of their friendship, and in them he fin the smartest ties, and dainty handkerchiefs to be worn in the pocket.

Roberta is lying on the couch in her room. Her cheeks hav fallen in -- the pupils of her eyes have grown immensely  large -- her face is as white as linen -- there are deep  blue circles under her eyes and the lips are parched.  Suffering terrible pain, Roberta lies there on the couch.
The blinds of Roberta's room are drawn only halfway.
And Clyde stands looking at them on the other side of the street in horror and consternation.
The blinds are drawn only halfway.
Clyde goes down the street and stops at a men's goods sto He stands for a few seconds before the door, obviously  nerving himself for a terrific effort, and suddenly goes

He pleasantly greets the salesman, clearly an old  acquaintance. Absent-mindedly picking out a tie, he lets  drop, as though a matter of little importance -- "By the -- I wanted to ask you about something. Perhaps you could tell me. One of the workmen at the factory, a young fello recently married, is very much worried over the condition his wife."  The salesman's face has grown annoyed; Clyde goes on, his nervousness, which he still endeavours to conceal,  increasing: "I don't know why they always come to me about such thing -- they seem to think I am very experienced --"  But Clyde's laugh rings false. The salesman continues to  smile with that smile that clearly covers annoyance, and gives an even greater attention to Clyde, who adds: "I'm in this city, I don't know anyone, and so I can't help hi But you've been here a long time, so I thought you might able to put me in a position to advise him."  The salesman looks around him, then comes nearer to Clyde and says: "Of course, I will be glad to help you, Mr.  Griffiths. Continue, what is the matter?"  And they start to whisper in very low voices, too low for the words to be distinguishable. Clyde is seen taking out notebook, and writing down an address. Then he sighs with relief. "I'll tell the man not to mention anyone's name," Clyde s as he thanks the salesman and exits from the shop.
Left alone, the salesman opens his eyes wide and whistles He is in possession of a fine piece of gossip and he know it.

Stealthily, to avoid remark, Clyde once more enters the  house of Roberta. A lamp is turned on in her room. From  outside the window, we hear Roberta's voice speaking: "No Clyde, I won't go alone. I'm too afraid. I shouldn't be a to explain anything to him. I shouldn't know what to do, how to begin or anything. You must go with me and we'll t him everything together -- or I won't go at all. No matte what happens."  "Hush! Hush!" Clyde is heard to say, and then the words  grow indistinguishable.

And indistinctly, maybe from one of the top floors, are  heard the feeble cries of a sick child. The child moans  pitifully. And against the light of the room lamp of  Roberta, Clyde's silhouette is seen as he pulls down the  blinds, and it grows dark all round.

Roberta is half lying on the bed. Clyde sits opposite her the couch. Pale, thin, Roberta stares at the light of the lamp, and says slowly: "I'll let you go." But, having sai this, she is unable longer to restrain herself and large  tears trickle down her wan face.  In the painful pause that follows we hear that someone is walking down the corridor, shuffling in bedroom slippers. Doors creak and we hear that an attempt is being made to  soothe the child. Roberta turns off the light. A pause.

In the darkness, they continue their conversation. She mu not be a drag on him, Roberta says, she is ready to face and afterwards she will try to make her way alone in the  world. Not quite alone, says Clyde, he will earn more mon and be able to help her. No, says Roberta, she knows it w be alone and she is ready. But what if the doctor be  unwilling?...
Again they hear the wailing of the sick child, a monotono low wail and sit silent, staring unseeing.
And they still stare unseeing, but now they travel in a  streetcar, and their stare is at the blank unreflecting  windows, behind which lies the town in darkness.
"Did you find out where the streetcar stops -- we won't h to walk far?" asks Roberta.
"It's quite near. A quarter of a mile, not more," answers Clyde.

An atmosphere of misery surrounds them as they sit in the streetcar. That cold and cut-off feeling of being the onl passengers in a streetcar passing through dark and isolat streets. The hoarse clanging of the streetcar bell. "Is he old or young -- do you know?" asks Roberta. Clyde  shakes his head.

"It would be easier for me if he were old."  They are silent again. Again the coldness and the enervat clanging of the bell. "Oh," moans Roberta, "if only the doctor is willing."  The streetcar passes into the darkness. 20. Roberta is seated in the depths of a huge armchair in the doctor's room. Through the half-opened door of his  consulting room the doctor and his family can be seen  finishing a copious dinner. Roberta is nervous. Now the  doctor is washing his hands in an adjoining room. Roberta closes her eyes.

The old doctor is in the room. He is absent-minded "What your complaint, how can I help you?" he asks. Roberta ope her eyes. She makes as if to answer, then, abashed, drops her head.  "Calm yourself, child," says the old doctor and, passing table, he comes and sits down beside her.
"Your name? Mrs ...?"  She answers: "Howard."  "Wife of Mister...?"
Clyde, nervously walking up and down the pavement, before the doctor's railing. He stops, bites his lips, rubs his  hands and nervously looks up at the house.

The doctor stands in the centre of the room, and says to confused Roberta: "To start with, my conscience will not permit me to compl with your request. Secondly, such an operation is dangero from a medical point of view, without even taking into  consideration that I should be breaking our State laws as well as ethical laws ...."  With an effort Roberta stands erect, she presses her hand together in anguish.
"You do not understand! You do not understand!" Roberta  says, trying to keep her tears back. "I told you an untru I have no husband; it must be done, it must be done!"
Clyde feels as though he had been lashed by a whip; he sl behind some shrubs with panicky, quick movements, as he s an automobile pass by.

The doctor's door slowly opens, and Roberta, broken by hi refusal, comes out. Mechanically she goes out into the  street and goes past the shrubs behind which Clyde is  concealed. He watches her, and from the way she is walkin and the expression of her face, he realises what has  happened. But he dare not leave his hiding place, because the cars passing down the street, and the pedestrians on pavements.
Roberta, as though hypnotised, goes further and further d the street, unseeingly, having forgotten about Clyde.
When the street empties, Clyde runs after her and joins h at a deserted spot.
At his question, Roberta only shakes her head, and wipes tears from her eyes. Completely bewildered and helpless,  they both stand there.

"You can leave me after, but now -- you have to help me - you have to --" And she starts to cry again. Clyde does not answer, and  merely drops his head. Roberta is wringing her hands, she shakes her head and continues pitifully:  "Oh, don't you see, I can't be alone with a child on my  hands, and no husband!"
And around them, a new spring. Over the factory chimneys  appears a soft, full May moon.
They reach Roberta's house.
"You said yourself you don't know anything else we can do and every extra day is dangerous for me. There's nothing  left for it, you must marry me -- right away."
Cowardly, and in his anxiety really sorry for her, Clyde  nods his head in confirmation of her words. In agony of  realisation he closes his eyes.
His eyes closed, standing alone in another place, on anot street, Clyde nods his head.
In a ravine, near the road, a miserable, half-fallen-in,  poor farmer's house.
An old woman is washing the laundry by the porch of this  house; behind the open window Roberta finishes a hat she been making. She tries it on, and talks to the old woman:
"What would you say, mother, if I suddenly got married?"  Continuing with her washing, the woman laughs at Roberta' question, and shakes her head.
"Oh, now I understand why you needed a new dress. Who is  he?"  "I can't name him -- yet, mother. But I think it will be  soon."  "Oh!" says the mother, surprised and pleased.
And at this moment an old, broken-down cart to which a th bony horse is harnessed, comes up to the house. "Good day Father," says Roberta.
"Hello, Bobby," answers a tall thin man, his tired worn f smiling up at his daughter.
The mother leaves her washing and goes across the dirty y towards her husband. And Roberta, resting a piece of pape on the window sill, starts a letter.
But when she begins to think, the happiness fades from he face, there is sorrow in her eyes and for a long while sh looks through the window, her hand holding up her head.
Misery, dirt and poverty are to be seen through the windo

The letter: Darling Clyde -- It was hard for me to  leave alone -- as you know. But I am  trying to calm myself, and now that we  have decided everything, and you will  come for me -- -- is written on the sheet of paper.
Along the dirty glass of the window, buzzing, crawl flies trying to escape into freedom.
But everything here is lovely --  green trees, everything is blooming.

And again Roberta looks with sorrowful eyes through the  window of the poverty stricken house. Among the darkness the dirt of the yard one thin flowering plant is blooming Several weak little trees are visible behind the fence. I can hear the buzzing of bees in  the garden under my window. Roberta whispers to herself what she has written.

"Bobby, you are wanted at the telephone," she hears her  mother's voice from the street. She runs out of the house crosses the road, runs into the entrance of a post office Excited, gasping or breath, she asks over the telephone:
"Clyde, is it you? Oh, it's terrible, terrible, Clyde. I  can't stand it any longer."
-- and, after hearing his answer, made in a voice of excu she continues the conversation:

"Oh, don't be angry. Clyde, don't be angry. I don't know to control myself. But whatever happens, you must, you mu do what we planned, Clyde. I'll write you a long letter,  because it helps me when I write to you. Clyde!...  Clyde!..." She hears no answer through the phone, calls him several  times, calls out his name, then, disappointed at the  unfinished conversation, hangs up the receiver and closes her eyes, because the tears are rolling down her cheeks.

Slowly Clyde hangs up the receiver, and exits from the  telephone booth onto the verandah of the restaurant of a  summer resort. He is in white tennis kit, a flower in his buttonhole, well-combed and handsome.  "Hurry, hurry, Clyde," Sondra cries out from a sports mod standing in the road by the restaurant.  Clyde's dark expression is replaced by one of pleasure, a on the run he jumps into the centre of the car, into a gr of young girls, merry and bright.
Roberta returns, entering the door of the decaying farm.

As the car drives, it drives into a new dream with Sondra this time a dream of the joys of sport and the bright  outdoors. Swimming, dancing, diving, racing, shooting, go tennis all are blended into a pictorial symphony that  matches with a symphony of music, laughter and the natura sounds. And each is instinct with Sondra, and the  personality of Sondra, and contributes to her growing cha for Clyde. Each scene, also, occasions some opportunity f intimacy. Now, on a tennis court, 15-love, 30-love, 40-lo rings out, the syllable of "love" accentuated. Now he is  pleading with her, on the crests of the waves, as they sw side by side, to run away with him, now immediately and,  though she refuses, the coquetry of her refusal chases th gloom from his eyes.  Ever the composition of the symphony rises, increasing th intimacy, and at last, as final movement, they are once m in a car, and we see flash past a white roadster, in the  front seats Clyde and Sondra.
In the back seats is a group of laughing young people. Th car stops at a crossroads, and Sondra asks Clyde to find the road from someone.
Clyde goes down into the ravine, to a miserable, dilapida house; on the post in front of it he sees the proprietor' name written in printed capitals TITUS ALDEN on a small  board.
Clyde is scared, hesitates and is about to flee, but  Roberta's father comes up to him and asks him how he can of help.
"How can we get to Twelfth Lake?" Clyde asks hurriedly,  impatient to retreat.

And the sickly old man starts a long, slow, detailed  explanation. And Clyde, barely hearing him, sees the piti ruins of the old house, and then, averting his head from he sees at the crossroads the dazzling car, and the laugh Sondra.

Without waiting to hear the end from Alden, he runs back the car, white and with compressed lips. He is anxious, a his hand trembles as he points the way, and Sondra surpri at his alarm quickly starts up the car.
The car, with a roaring of its powerful engine, flies pas the house. The father stamps heavily in. Roberta looks up from her letter and asks casually:  "Father, who was it?"
"I don't know, Bobby. Some rich no-accounts who lost thei road." The sound of the engine fades as the car recedes ever  farther away.
Clyde throws open the door of his rooms. He is still whit still worried, still distressed. He goes up to the table sees on it a letter, in Roberta's handwriting.

Annoyed and without pleasure he opens the envelope, and  turns immediately to the last lines:  We must get married. I insist on it. I  have the right to. You have allowed all  this time to pass in silence and unless  I hear from you before noon Friday all  your friends shall know how you have  treated me. But I will not wait and suffer  one hour more. Dazed, he stares at the letter, then lets his head drop  forward onto it, his eyes closed.
Then he raises his head again. His hands pull the letter  towards him.
And as it moves it discloses a newspaper that lay beneath it. Immediately in front of him is the paragraph:

head_text.subj: ACCIDENTAL DOUBLE TRAGEDY AT LAKE PASS
UPTURNED CANOE AND FLOATING HATS REVEAL

text: He reads it at first mechanically, without comprehending.

The girl's body has been found but remains unidentified.  The second victim has not yet been recovered. Fifteen  years ago in this spot a similar accident occurred, but t body of the man was never found.

Clyde finishes reading the article, throws the paper off table, turns out the lamp, and sits wearily down on the  couch. And suddenly he hears a whisper:  "And what if Roberta and you --"  And in the dark corner, he imagines he sees an overset bo Jumping up, Clyde turns on the light.  He sits down on the couch again, nervous and shivering, h picks up the paper he had thrown away and rereads the  article. And while he is rereading it with wide-open eyes the whisper from afar gradually creeps up till it forms t word: "KILL".  In a strange, gradual way the phrase spoken by the whispe forms and forms until at last it pronounces and repeats t whole word: "KILL! KILL!"  And from this moment the action begins to work along the  line of the thoughts of a distracted man, leaping from on fact to another, suddenly stopping -- departing from sane logic, distorting the real union between things and sound all on the background of the insistent and infinite  repetition of scraps of the description in the newspaper. In this scene, in which the idea of murder is born to Cly he acts separately from the background, which keeps chang after him, either dashing in a mad tempo when the backgro is slow, then falling when there is no reason to fall, th unsteady on a rock, then transformed into stone-like  motionlessness in the midst of a busy street.

With the aid of the technical use of transparencies this  effect of an inharmony between the actions of Clyde and h surroundings can be attained. Around him is first his roo then a street in busy movement, or the lake, or the mean  dwelling of Roberta, or the summer residence of Sondra at Twelfth Lake, or the machines in the factory, or running  trains, or the stormy sea, in each setting of which he  moves, his movements being discordant with the scene.

And the same with the sounds. These are likewise distorte and a whisper becomes the whistle of a storm, and the sto cries out "Kill", or the whistle of the storm becomes the movement of the street, the wheels of a streetcar, the cr of a crowd, the horns of motorcars, and all beat out the  word: "Kill! Kill!" And the street noises become the roar of the factory machines, and the machines also roar out  "Kill! Kill!"

Or the roar of the machines descends to a low whisper and it whispers again: "Kill! Kill!" And at this moment a  pleasant, unemotional voice slowly reads the newspaper  article: Fifteen years ago a similar accident occurred, b the body of the man was never found.

And at the climax of this symphony of madness Clyde jumps out of his nightmare, perspiring, dishevelled, excited. H runs to a telephone booth and calls up Roberta. Through t phone he speaks to her in a hoarse voice.  "This is Clyde."  He tries to put tenderness into his voice but in his effo there is too much affection. His voice, through the phone sounds loving and soft; it seems unbelievable that a man his state of frenzy could be so kind.  "I'll come to you, Roberta darling. You must wait for me days. The 3rd of July I'll meet you at 15th Station at  eleven o'clock, and we'll go rowing on the lake, and we'l get married, we'll get married."  And with trembling hand Clyde hangs up the receiver, and leans against the wall, so as not to fall, while Roberta' sorrowful face lights up in trust and happiness.
On a small railway station, away from the crowds of peopl Roberta is sitting on her trunk.

Clyde is seen coming along a side street leading to the  station. He is walking slowly, carefully, making himself  inconspicuous behind the trucks of baggage, pausing behin large baskets -- he sees Roberta and, concealed, watches  her.

Roberta is pale and thin. She looks pathetic, and is  dressed in a new, homemade costume. Her hat is also new.  Clyde's face expresses both shame and dislike. Neverthele he takes a few steps forward, so that she may catch sight of him.

Roberta sees him. A happy look comes into her face and sh goes to the ticket office to buy her ticket. And as she  leaves the office -- Clyde approaches it, and buys his own ticket.  She watches him, notices his light-grey suit, his new str hat, the highly polished shoes, his grip and his portable camera. And a feeling of pride floods her at the sight of him. She smiles, and turns her head away from him,  pretending to be a stranger, as though she did not know h Clyde starts, because it seems to him that an old man in worn suit, with a bird cage wrapped up in paper, is looki at him with suspicion, not taking his eyes off him. Clyde's knees are weak, and his hands are trembling. Whil waiting for the train he paces up and down the platform,  starting nervously at every engine whistle.
With a great roar the train pulls in.

Only the eleventh, a "Yes,  yes" as though from the hardware dealer sounds out of tun with the others, coming a tiny bit too quickly and too  eagerly.

And by degrees, as the human voices in the courtroom grow fainter, the noise on the square before the court buildin grows stronger, and when, out of the doors of the buildin Mason appears, a thunderous "Hurrah" is heard, and greeti are roared out by the crowd. Mason is carried across the  square on their shoulders. "Hurrah for justice!" -- "Hurr for the new Judge!" -- "Hurrah for Mason!"

And in an empty room of the courthouse, from whence the  joyous cries of the crowd can be heard, Clyde is dictatin telegram to Jephson.  Mother, I have been found guilty. Come. Clyde. 28. And fresh yells are to be heard: "Hurrah for Orville!" -- "God is with you, Judge!" -- "Hurrah -- Hurrah --  Hurrah!" --
A train pulls into the dark station. The lonely figure of Clyde's mother descends the steps of the carriage. She go through the empty station -- the dark empty street -- the dark courtyard.

The dark building of the prison. A lantern over the priso gates, and the mother enters, and once again it is dark o the screen. Out of the darkness appears a prison cell, in which Mrs. Griffiths is sitting, holding her son's head i her huge hands. Like a little boy, Clyde sobs, as he says "I -- didn't do it --"  And the mother's large hand strokes the boy's hand, and  tears well up in her eyes.
The barely visible structure of the prison building fades out completely in the darkness.

And a train comes directly forward into the camera. And t wheels are beating their normal rhythm, and its bell chim out in its normal way, but it seems as though the wheels  were repeating "Death -- death -- death" and as though th bell were tolling at a funeral. And in a compartment Clyd is sitting, joined to a guard by manacles.

The train stops at a station. Clyde looks out of the wind and a crowd of young girls and boys assemble, snapping hi with their cameras, bringing him bouquets of flowers, and greeting him. The girls look at him with admiration -- is not the hero of a tragedy of love?
"Good luck, Mr. Griffiths." "Good luck, Clyde."  And Clyde smiles at them, smiles a boyish smile.  "Your mother will help," someone cries out from the crowd
Smiling proudly in their importance, the two detectives p Clyde away from the window.  The train leaves....

In the office of Belknap and Jephson. Belknap is seated,  Jephson standing. Before them is Clyde's mother. The  crudeness of her clothes has been effaced for them by the earnestness of her manner. Jephson is explaining to her t there are no funds for appeal. The Griffiths of Lycurgus  have withdrawn their support. She listens taking in only part of what they are saying. Then suddenly rises to her  feet:  "The Lord will not desert me. I know it. He has declared  himself to me. I will trust him and he will guide me."

In pagan astonishment and some admiration Belknap and  Jephson are taken aback by this evangelistic fervour.  Then -- Why not? Jephson strikes his hand to his head, and speaks animatedly to Belknap. It could be done. Why not? The onl chance to raise the money. There are religious people,  people of faith, everywhere. Let her speak for her son an take a collection.
"I am trying to gather enough money to pay or an appeal f my son."  -- says Clyde's mother, turning to two men. She sits in t small confirmation room of a church.
"I should like to preach in your church."  "We cannot help you," answers a grey-haired man. "Even if is innocent of murder -- there is the adultery -- that we cannot endorse in our community."
Out of the doors of another church comes the sorrowful  mother.
And within two grey-haired women talk of her.  "Her teaching is suspicious. She belongs to no congregati of any official church and we did right in refusing to le her preach."
"I am sorry, sister," a well-built Negro preacher says to Clyde's mother. "Our church cannot give you its hall. It only for coloured people."  And, ever more discouraged, she leaves the room.

The apple trees are in blossom -- ivy is crawling up the  walls -- the grapevine curls itself about the iron railin The white flowers of sweet peas and the yellow of  nasturtiums crowd around the prison-cell window. The whit building of the prison is set in the midst of green shrub and moss.

Again the moss-covered window, and behind the window, in cell, sits Clyde. He is dressed in the striped uniform of prisoner, and on his back is number 772. He feels his sha head, his sunken cheeks and trembles as if cold.  "Where am I?" -- asks Clyde.  And from the next cell a voice is heard:  "In the Death House, on Murderers' Row."  And Clyde shuts his eyes, and helplessly falls on his bun

A Mother's Appeal for her Son.
And boys in the street are handing out leaflets on which advertised the plea of Clyde's mother.

A sombre, serious crowd of people pass through the tawdry entrance of the Burlesque theatre, pass the posters of  indecent, undraped women. And on the scene, with a  background of the Burlesque drops on the stage, among  plaster statues of gaudy women, Clyde's mother speaks in sincere way, her large figure in bleak contrast with the  surrounding atmosphere.

She speaks with faith, feelingly, touchingly, as a mother can speak of her son, and it makes the Burlesque girls cl in their sparkles and feathers cry as they wait at the ba for rehearsal; even the electrician at his signal board i intent.

A tray is passed through the congregation for offerings.  "What is this -- a church?" asks a merry young girl, comi late for rehearsal, as she enters backstage.  "Hush," the others quiet her, as they blow their noses.

And when Clyde's mother leaves the theatre, she has to pa a row of burlesque girls ready for the rehearsal. In her  hands she holds the bag of money, two girls break line an ask respectfully to offer coins. Clyde's mother smiles as she passes through the exit door and she hears neither th cheap music, nor the hoarse singing of the rehearsal whic has started.
"Clyde," a voice is heard saying in the dark.
Clyde jumps off his bunk in his cell. "A note for you," a voice says, and a hand gives him an envelope.
He unfolds the note. It is typewritten and reads:  Clyde -- This is so that you will not  think that someone once dear to you has  utterly forgotten you. She has suffered  much, too -- Sondra.
He presses it to his lips, runs up to the window, looks o at the sun and repeats words that he said once before, lo ago:
"To live -- how good it is."
"Hello, Clyde, hello, son," he hears his mother's voice a sees her come to him.

His mother forces herself to show no anxiety, she says:  "The Governor has promised to see us, son, and we have a  little money together, not much --" He throws himself into her arms, and presses his head upo her lap, once more a boy.

"Everything will be all right, Clyde," she croons, stroki the head in her lap. "Everything will be all right. You  didn't do it. You didn't do it."  "Yes, mummy, I didn't do it." The warmth of her faith, th tenderness of her protecting hand, her soothing voice  envelop Clyde. He is a child of years ago.  "You didn't do it -- the Lord will deliver you," soothes mother. "My boy could never think of such a thing."  Clyde snuggles closer. Gone is the tension of his long  ordeal. His soul relaxes. The comforting hand caresses hi

"I did -- think of it, mummy," says Clyde. And the mother caress slows, her fingers have become stiff and her face  set. And Clyde rubs his cheek against the hands that are  now of wood.  "But I never -- never -- never did it, mummy." 18. The door opens and Jephson enters. He speaks hurriedly to Mrs. Griffiths.

"We must go now. We are due at the Governor's. Come."  The mother rises, she presses Clyde in her great protecti arms and responds to his kiss. With a trace of absentness she leaves the cell with Jephson.
"Good luck, mother, good luck," Clyde calls after her. An once more Clyde goes to the window, Sondra's note in his  hand and tears of happiness in his eyes.
The unfriendly house of the Governor.
The great study of the Governor.

In front of a great desk stands the Governor compassionat by the side of the mother. Quietly he asks: "Can you, Mrs Griffiths, can you from the bottom of your soul tell me t you believe him innocent?"  She turns to him to say "Yes", but having said: "My  son ...." she stops.
Her eyes open wide as she hears the voice of Clyde, softl "I did -- think of it, mummy --"  -- and she closes her eyes. Her head drops on her chest,  there is silence in the room.

The shrill sound of a bell. The mother starts, opens her  eyes. The Governor removes his hand from the bell. He  stands on the other side of the desk. He is important, fu of power and unapproachable.  "Excuse me," he says, "but there is no reason to reopen t case. God will help you, mother. My prayers go with you." The door is opened and automatically she leaves the room, but, as the door closes behind her, she comes to herself, cries out, and turns back towards the door.  "My son is innocent," she says.  But the door does not open.

Darkness spreads over the screen, and at the same time, w a fierce rattle, an iron shutter is drawn up, disclosing cell window. On the floor is a clean brass cuspidor. A so broom is carefully cleaning the space around it. The broo is sweeping between the feet of the chair. And --  -- on these feet hang leather thongs with heavy buckles, from the chair onto the floor falls a shadow.  There is a heavy iron door in this room. And from behind door can be heard a song.
Clyde and his mother are singing psalms. In the condemned cell, clad in black, sing Clyde and his fanatically exalt mother.

And suddenly Clyde breaks off in his singing, and at the  knees of his mother he clasps her with a cry:  "To live -- I want to live!"  And through the window is the bright sunlit courtyard of prison, all in green and in flowers, and on it is heard: "To live --"  And again we see the cell window, and within it is the  mother praying, and the camera receding discloses to us t now she is alone, on her knees and singing; more faintly  now, but more majestically.  Slowly the heavy iron door closes.
And against the background of the spring fields and sky  slides from left to right the barred gate of the prison. from right to left the solid inner gate of the prison.

And the blinds and shutters of the windows come sliding d and sliding down, shutting out the landscapes and the sky light -- life --  And with their closing, cease the trilling of grasshopper in the meadows, the singing of the birds and the sound of human voices, and as the last sound is gone the last shut descends closing out the prison bars against the white an there is blackness.  Blackness and quiet.
A sharp crackle and the sharp light of an electric contac -- and again quiet -- again blackness.
Grey smoke rises against the dull sky and loses itself in the quiet air.

A tall chimney, a roof; the camera descends past the wind and balconies of a mean building, and the lower descends camera the stronger sound the voices of a little choir  singing psalms.  In a dirty lane by a mission, surrounded by a crowd of  curiosity seekers, to the sound of a harmonium, some stre preachers are singing, as at the beginning of the picture There they stand, but now the hair of the mother is white snow, the father is old and ailing, and Esta is grown to sickly woman and, instead of Clyde, as small as when we f saw him and resembling him, is her little seven-year-old How long since you wrote to Mother?  -- says a notice by the entrance to the mission.  "Everybody's happy"  -- sings the white-haired, broken mother. Pitifully wheez the harmonium and the strains of "Everybody's happy" fade distantly as the scene FADES OUT.
